ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Analyzing amplifier circuits and small signal representations. Some physics of transistors as well
A more in depth knowledge of MOSFETs, BJTs, amplifiers, and other essential analog circuits
Circuit theory, MOSFET and BJT applications, multi layer circuits

Prof Xia's course is a solid overview of circuit components like amplifiers (diodes, op-amps, MOSFETS, BJTs) and their many variations and configurations. As an EECS major, this was an elective choice I decided to take to try and get a better sense of circuits and their inner workings. I believe I did leave this class with a better introduction to the circuit world, especially since the lectures were also filled with information about how we might see a certain configuration in industry.
A little more about circuit analysis

We learned how to solve circuits involving transistors and amplifiers. We also learned concepts to consider when designing circuits. Furthermore, we considered real world aspects of circuits outside of ideal models.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Labs were generally pretty good. TAs were very helpful and they helped improve conceptual knowledge of the class. Lectures were okay, they could get kind of confusing sometimes and the professor goes pretty fast.

Prof Xia is very approachable and understanding, which I really appreciated. I think one thing that could be improved would be to more explicitly state what we should take away from lecture, since oftentimes they could be difficult to understand but we really only needed to solidly know the basic concepts. The labs were fun to do, but sometimes I felt like neither I nor other students/TAs fully understood certain questions in our lab reports. Some other strengths were that the workload, homework, and exams were very fair.

Strengths - Prof Xia explains the concepts clearly in class

Weakness - the labs dont always work and a bit hard to understand the underlying theory
The lectures were a bit hard to follow.

The lectures were packed with information and engaging which I appreciated. It made sure that I paid full attention to the material. Prof Xia would also make sure to include a lot of examples to clarify certain phenomenon. The structure of the course material was also very clear from the start, so it would help gauge which weeks would be busier. The TAs for this class were amazing in their feedback and lab help. 

The course could be improved by providing feedback or solutions for the homeworks sooner, but with only two TAs its understandable why it would take while.
The textbook is great. Regular quizzes that tested concepts rather than problem solving might help students better understand the material.
The labs in the course were very well made. They extended on what we learned in class, were thought-provoking, and provided stimulating tasks for us to complete.

Strengths: reasonable work load, reasonable lab
Weaknesses: maybe adding an extra TA office hour?

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Meh. If you really want to get into the details of transistors and amplifiers sure

I feel like the only people that are interested in taking this course are already majoring in/interested in electrical engineering, so to those people, I would say yes! Analog circuit design is not my favorite topic in EE, but I really wanted to make sure that I had a good foundation in circuits so I decided to take this class. I definitely do not regret it--I feel more comfortable with circuit analysis, and I also feel like I now somewhat understand the higher-level things we glossed over in EE 201 and EE 203. I thought this class was well-organized and had a classroom culture that was not super stressful.
Good to have an in-depth understanding of circuits

Yes. I think it's a pretty approachable introduction into circuit configurations and components. The workload is manageable and lectures are very engaging. As an elective, I felt it was a good addition to my EE background.
You get as much out of this course as you put into it. Most of my learning came from the textbook if thats cool with you

I would recommend. I think this is a very well taught EE class with a manageable course load and interesting topic. Sometimes the frequency of the labs were difficult, but the Professor always seemed aware of our workload and made an effort to ensure the labs didnt take the full 3 hours! Otherwise, one of the best EE classes Ive taken while at Yale and think it would be good for any major/non-major student to take.
